segments.text: Oral interview with Sandy Livingood, 18 August 1988.
Your first tour in Vietnam was June 1964 to December 1964 and you were a Civil Affairs and Psychological Warfare Officer with Special Forces 1st Corps RVN.
In the beginning, what kind of special forces training did you have before you went?
Had you had any at all?
I had not had any special forces training at all.
Transferred from the 173rd Airborne Brigade on Okinawa to the 1st Special Forces Group.
Without any special forces training, I'd had, of course, the airborne training and
Where did you train?
For the airborne training in the States?
Yes, I went through airborne school in Georgia in 1965.
Had you had any kind of jungle warfare training?
Yes, with the 173rd we'd had jungle training in northern Oklahoma and on a local town called Ariel Moody.
I'm not sure exactly where it is.
I'm not sure that we ever got to see a map at that time, and if we did, it's been so long.
As I recall, it wasn't too far from Formosa.
It was one of the, I believe, one of the Ryukyu groups.
I'm not sure.
What percentage of that kind of training do you think was specifically geared towards Vietnam?
Probably none of the training itself was geared towards Vietnam.
It was geared towards reaction to a threat within Southeast Asia, and possibly on the mainland, possibly on one of the islands.
We trained in the 173rd to meet all the threats that were thought of.
strictly war planning type of training.
Before you went the first time, did you get any language training in Vietnamese or French?
Yes.
As I recall, I had about three weeks of training
in a branch of the Language School, the Department of Defense Language School in Okinawa.
It was survival training.
It was language survival.
It was the very basics and enough to give us an idea of how the language was spoken to develop some accent and to
give us the ability to make ourselves understood to a very limited extent.
So with that limited experience or language training, what kind of language problems did you encounter when you got to Vietnam, or how was the language situation dealt with when you got there?
At the time that I arrived in 1964, we had a
fairly large number of people there who spoke English to some extent.
Interpreters were made available to us.
As a matter of fact, I had an interpreter clerk in my section when I arrived.
He'd been hired by previous Civil Affairs Science Officers to
work for them as an interpreter, translator, clerk.
What specifically were your duties as a psyops officer on civil affairs times civil affairs officer?
That is not easy to explain.
I guess I can best explain it by saying that I was in charge of supervision, assistance, and planning
of the Civil Affairs, Psychological Warfare Operations, or the Special Forces in the First Corps, known as I-Corps, Republic of Vietnam.
I coordinated and assisted the aid teams.
Those were the teams that were out in the provinces working with the
special forces teams, and with the Civil Irregular Defense Group, they were the troops being trained by both U.S. special forces and with the Vietnamese special forces.
They were placed in the villages or around the villages, and the best I recall about
battalion strength and they established an outpost and patrol from the outposts in varying areas of operation, areas of operation varying in size, varying in size.
Some maybe 10 square miles, others up to 50 or 60 square miles, and most of the camps
at that particular time in June of 1964 were in the populated areas in the lowland at the base of the mountainous areas.
These were lowland camps, but they were close to the mountains.
with the exception of the one camp at Ashau.
They were, and again the one at Kashan, they were normally at the very edge of the fairly densely populated areas.
What kinds of problems did you have training the RVN?
We were not training ARVN as such.
These were paramilitary type troops that we were looking at, and I was not directly involved with the training.
My job was directed towards, as we later call it, winning the hearts and minds of the people.
But our job was to

ensure that it was possible that we would have a fairly close rapport and interface between the Special Forces and with the local villages so that we would have some close bond between the two elements there, the civil government and the military, as well as the population.
What would you say were the relationships or the relations between the Vietnamese and the Americans in 1964?
There was a great deal of trust between the local special forces teams and the villagers.
And in this way we were trying and we felt that our job was to further the government of Vietnam image with the local people.
It was not a situation where the U.S. Special Forces people wanted to become the father figure for the villagers.
And we always tried to take with us when we were doing our medical calls and sick calls and so forth, we wanted to take with us Vietnamese special forces.
And we always had interpreters, of course we had guards and Vietnamese soldiers, the paramilitary.
with us and we attempted wherever we could to make it known to them that we were there under the sponsorship of the government.
What do you think was the relationship with the South Vietnamese government and the peasants?
Very little.
As a matter of fact, this is true throughout my entire

experience in vietnam the local villagers really did not identify with the with the government itself they identified with their local village chief and they knew who he was but so far as having any identification with the government in saigon or the government in
The North, they really had none.
It was a matter that in most cases the Vietnamese are Oriental people.
Whether they be Chinese or ethnic Vietnamese or ethnic Cambodian or ethnic Indian, they still had the Oriental

outlook and their life was based on the family and the extended family and their life was based on their religion and on their day-to-day child that they did not identify even with even district government province or national government now the relationship between the government and the local villagers
was represented by, as I said before, the building chief.
And on occasion they would be visited by district and province officials.
At that time they were mostly military officials.
The district chief would be maybe an army captain or an army major, depending on the size of the district.
And the province chief would be either a lieutenant colonel or a colonel in the Army of the Republic of Vietnam Army.
How was the relationship between the ARVN and the U.S. military?
During this period of time, I was not really concerned with the Army of the Republic of Vietnam, as a matter of fact.
At that particular time, there were only about two Arvin divisions in the whole of I-Corps.
I believe this has been many years ago, and I'm trying to recall.
I believe it was the 1st and 2nd Divisions.
And one of those divisions was stationed at Way and Point 3.
And I do not recall the location where the 2nd Division was stationed.
But there was no interaction that I ever observed between the Army of Vietnam and the local populace.
I guess you might say that I was too far out in the woods and the jungle to really see them.
What kinds of project buildings were you involved in?
Some of the, I helped to build dispensaries.
When I say I helped, I personally did very little out with the A-teams.
I was primarily a facilitator.
In other words, I was able to give them blueprints.
I was able to give, and you'll have to realize that a concrete block or a
compressed earth and cement block building.
It doesn't take much blueprints, but I was able to give them some idea of the number of bricks that it might take.
I was able to get the cement for them.
And just to put it quickly, I
I worked helping them build their own dispensaries, get them the white paint and so forth, and to approve the funds that were necessary for them to buy the materials if the materials were necessary.
Of course, bamboo is readily available in most areas of Vietnam, and a lot of their construction was with bamboo, and even the more permanent buildings, some of them had bamboo materials in them.
but I was able to get cut timber and lumber for them.
Let's see, we had soil factories, and that is a grandiose term for maybe building a communal building in one of the villages and obtaining soil machines and quality.
And these were supposed to be semi-cottage industry where the local ladies could begin to sew, for instance, uniforms for the CIDG.
And we furnished initially the, I guess you'd call it seed money.
We furnished the materials and the sewing machines and so forth.
And they furnished the labor to build the
built a house, and then they sold their product to the local people and were able to buy more material and carry on making a little pocket money.
And it was hoped to be the beginning of industry, something other than strictly rice paddy work.
In the area of the city of Da Nang,
which was my personal responsibility as part of the B team, which had the first corps at that time.
I worked with an American, actually a Canadian missionary who had been in Southeast Asia for many, many years.
And I'm saying 30 to 40 years he'd been working in Indochina.
not only in Vietnam, but also in Cambodia.
And he was sponsoring, through his church, an orphanage, a leprosarium, and a tubercularium.
I think that's the way you pronounce it, tuberculosis sanitary.
And the leprosarium was just beginning to get off the ground, and I did a lot of work there.
people working for me that were experts in construction, engineers.
And with the orphanage, the team itself, the orphanage had already been built.
But we worked in that area considerably, helping them with additional things such as a bath house and recreational construction.
and even, as I recall, a small merry-go-round for them.
What about strategic hamlets?
Were you involved in any of the building and relocating of the refugees to strategic hamlets?
In 1964, the term was strategic hamlet.
I don't believe it had been invented.
Possibly so, but if it was, it had not reached my area.
And these strategic hamlets, if they were existing, were existing further back towards the coast.
I was not personally involved with the strategic handlers there.
Were you aware of infiltration on the demilitarized zone by the Viet Cong at that time or vice versa?
Were there any special forces groups, hunter-killer teams going into the DMZ?
Around the DMZ, we were not aware of it.
If it was going on,
I believe at that time most of our activity was coming from the Laotian area.
Primarily the DMZ was east of the Kashan area and that would probably have been the area of operations of the 1st Division.
our team there at cation was patrolling primarily in the islands around the special forces camp over to the ocean border and i will just comment that it's been my recollection and was then that until
July of that year, it was what we call a friendly war.
There wasn't a lot of contact between the, there wasn't a great deal of military contact between the BC and the government forces.
The reason I say that is because the BC
efforts were by and large directed against the civil population.
They killed doctors, they killed village chiefs, they killed school teachers.
It appeared at that time that the effort was being, in our area, the effort was being carried out against the educated people.
They were attempting to eliminate education.
In relation to your duties as psyops, officer, what kind of psyops tactics were y'all using at that time, if any?
Well, we felt that civil affairs itself, the civic action programs that we were using were psychological warfare.
But in addition to those, we had available to us
aviation assets to some extent.
We had printing assets available in Saigon.
We dropped leaflets.
We dropped little care packets, we called them, containing tobacco, cigarettes, chewing gum, and a small comic book wrapped in a baggie, I guess you'd call it.
We dropped those on the villages
along the border, those that we could find on both sides of the border, I think.
You have to understand that once you get into the highlands there, that the border is not marked on the ground as a little black line.
And I'm sure there were occasions that we found villages on both sides, and possibly we did drop into Latinas.
absolutely that on at least one occasion that I did drop some of the propaganda leaflets and care packets into a village on the west side of the international border.
And I was never sure even then that either government knew where the border was.
We had also
loudspeakers, aviation-mounted loudspeakers that had a tremendous coverage.
They were loud.
We played Vietnamese tapes.
Now, I'm sure that in retrospect that this had nothing to do with the civil populace, but the only possible use it could have been would to be maybe
discouraging, playing on the nerves of the Viet Cong who were in there.
And you must remember that the Highlands were not Vietnamese, that they were Montagnards.
And this was our biggest task because we did not have Montagnard speakers, Montagnard people.
they had languages that no one had ever translated.
And each of the Montagnard tribes, their languages could be as separate as the languages of the American Indian.
And a distance of 15 miles or less that the language of the tribe would change
or the area would change, were that they were mutually unintelligible, that people from 15 miles away could not speak to each other and understand.
And I remember also that they were still in the Stone Age and possibly still are.
I don't know.
But with the exception of those who were around
there were very few tribes which had become even civilized.
The situation was a little bit different.
In I-Corps, the brew at Kashan, I believe that was the tribe,
were reasonably civilized, but they had just come out of the Stone Age or the Bamboo Age, which hit them.
Do you see a lot of culture clashes?
As far as clashing goes, I can't say that I did.
It was peaceful coexistence with the cultures as far as I can tell.
And primarily the
The one I am most familiar with where I saw the Montagnards in large numbers was at the village of Keishon, and they co-existed quite well.
They would hold their, when there was a market day, the Montagnard and the Vietnamese and the Chinese were all right at the market, and they bought and sold to one another.
depending upon what they had to sell and what they wanted to buy.
In the Khe Sanh area, they have been civilized long enough that many of the modern yards work with the French plantation owners, called the plantation owners, and they work with the Vietnamese
in the villages, or in the village of Khe Sanh.
But culture clash, I think they each maintained their own culture as they saw fit.
There didn't seem to be any real put down of the Montagnards by the local Vietnamese.
As a matter of fact, many of the
paramilitary CIDG.
In the Khe Sanh area, there were Monitors.
They had been enlisted and trained by the Vietnamese, and they had their own way, their own
their own diet, so to speak, and they ate what they could get.
As a matter of fact, throughout my experiences in Vietnam, it appeared to me that both the Vietnamese Moniards and Laotians and Cambodians ate what they could get.
As far as the religion goes, of course the Vietnamese were either Buddhist or
Protestant or Catholic Christians, and the Montagnards were animist.
But that did not seem to be anything unusual, with the exception of the big cities such as Saigon, and I guess primarily Saigon as far as I can recall.
There did not seem to be any religious conflict during, at least that I saw.
As you probably know, history tells us that President Zim and his brother and sister-in-law were fanatic Catholic, and they did in fact favor the
Catholics of Vietnam, but as far as being intolerant of religion, there did not appear to be any at any place I was in Vietnam.
What about the Americans in Vietnam?
Did you yourself experience culture shock, or how did you react to the different cultures?
I had no real culture shock.
I had been in the Orient before and I think that I was personally adult enough to realize that everyone to their own way.
As you know, we've been on Okinawa before I went to Vietnam.
You know that I had been in Korea prior to going to Vietnam, Japan, and several other places.
So culture shock was not something that was likely to arise with me.
I was one of the oldest soldiers to go there, and I had learned by this time to expect the unexpected.
And to respect, hopefully, the culture of other peoples without being condescending or to look with disfavor upon it.
But were there problems with some of the other people that weren't so educated?
Yes, it was not.
Not especially true within the Special Forces teams.
They did on occasion have some conflict with the philosophy of warfare within the Special Forces.
The primary conflicts that I saw in the Serbs was the
apparent unwillingness of the Vietnamese to press forward with an attack or to pursue the enemy.
This was normal throughout, and there were exceptions with the Vietnamese.
The philosophy of the American is once you attack, you attack in strength.
You attack with everything that you can bring to bear upon the enemy.
And once you have started him to retreat, you pursue with vigor.
This was not the overall philosophy of the Vietnamese.
were, in my estimation, in many cases, timid.
Don't take this to mean that they all were.
Some were absolute tigers and would fight through everything they had at the enemy and pursue as a tiger.
Did you think that we could win the war when you left in 1964 in December?
Yes, I believe that the policies that we were pursuing at that time were the policies that would, in fact, win the war.
At that particular time, when I left, there were no American troops as such.
There were no American ground troops on the ground in Vietnam.
Little did we know what was going to happen.
I think that we were succeeding using the policies that we were pursuing at that time.
Which was to gain the friendship of the people?
Pacification.
Did you know any civilians that first time?
Yes, I did.
I knew a few civilians, not a great number.
I had, as a result of my type of work, I had come to know some peasants.
I had come to know some merchants and the Vietnamese people themselves.
I like them, and I think probably they liked me.
On the other hand, I could be wrong.
They could have been trying to take advantage of that friendship for whatever reason, but I doubt it.
How was the esprit de corps of the Special Forces and the Americans that were over there?
Very high, very high.
The Americans in Vietnam at that time knew that we had a mission, and they believed in their government.
They believed in the methods that we were using, and I believe for that reason.
As you know, Special Forces is and was all volunteers.
And I believe that you'll find a higher discreet accord in volunteers.
And each of them had more or less volunteered two or three times in order to get where they were.
And they were doing quite well.
They believed in what they were doing.
When you believe in what you're doing, you're free to court.
It's always normal.
When you left Vietnam, did the US military ever ask you what would be better ways to train our people that were going over there?
Did they debrief you?
I had a debriefing, but
It was primarily directed towards civil affairs, psychological warfare, civic action.
Did they ask suggestions of how to get the Vietnamese people to help the Americans, or to help us?
I don't recall what they ever did.
In the year that you were gone, what did you do, and did you get any training that was related to Vietnam?
you're asking about the period of time between December of 64 and December of 64 as I recall I trained with special forces in Taiwan I trained with special forces in Korea and
Both of those were extended exercises from, I believe, each one of them was three months or more in those areas.
And we acted in joint exercises in both places with U.S. Special Forces and Korean Special Forces and
the Republic of China Special Forces were operating in a similar type scenario.
The environments, of course, were different in Korea and Taiwan.
Taiwan being more jungle-like and Korea being rather mountainous.
As I recall, the scenario was that he joined U.S. and
would go into an area, recruit and train guerrillas.
And of course, this was carried out under the auspices of the respective governments and in cooperation with the U.S. Special Forces.
On the island of Okinawa, we carried out several
small exercises, but I was not directly involved with those.
My primary duties were preparation of area studies and studying of the various countries within Southeast Asia.
At approximately the time that I came back, possibly even before I don't recall the time sequence,
Special Forces Group headquarters was re-designated Special Action Forces Asia.
And they were given the responsibility, as I recall, sometime during this time, of reacting with Special Forces and regular troops in each country
of our area of operations.
And this was from, as I recall, Burma, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam, Taiwan, Korea.
And I don't believe we had a Japan team, but I do know that one of our teams did go to Japan during that time.
I did not
Were you able to use your experiences in Vietnam to facilitate any of that training or to help you?
Certainly, certainly.
But it was somewhat difficult to overlay the training or the experiences in Vietnam in, for instance, Republic of China, Taiwan.
since their ideas of civil affairs did not exactly coincide with ours, and we were a guest in that particular country at the time.
And while we could influence our own people, it was sometimes difficult at the higher headquarters, and I was in each case at the headquarters,

not with one of the field teams, it was difficult to influence the high-ranking Chinese or high-ranking Korean officers towards this area because they were primarily interested in the morale and welfare of their own troops and the guerrillas rather than the

indigenous or civilian or local populace and those type of things were primarily I could influence our own teams and possibly gain a little headway towards the idea of winning hearts and minds and influencing the from my area
down through the American team, back across to either the Chinese or Korean team, back across to the civilian populace in that way, rather than trying to bring it down from the top.
It worked better coming up from the bottom.
And your second?
Touring Vietnam from December of 65 to December 66, your Civil Affairs and Psychological Worker Staff Officer with the United States 25th Infantry Division.
Chu Chi, RVM, and 3rd Corps Area.
Did you, do you feel you did a better job the second time in Vietnam?
Will?
Or were you more cynical?
I don't think I was ever cynical.
I still believed in what I was doing.
What was your job?
25th Division.
U.S. 25th Division.
I don't think that I ever became cynical concerning the reasons that we were there.
As a matter of fact, I was probably to use the term gum-poe in this particular area of civil affairs and psyops at that time.
After having studied everything that I possibly could concerning the areas of pacification of the civilian populace, I believed that it could be done.
I was probably influenced a lot by my studies and the successes that the
British had had in Malaya.

And I had believed that properly utilized, and this is probably about the time that the term strategic hamlet came about, that at least when I first became aware of it, I thought this was going to operate and I thought it was going to work.
And I believed that it could.
What was the purpose of Strategic Hamlet?

The Strategic Hamlet was, as I remember, you take some of the local people, some of the boys and men, train them, give them a certain amount of training, give them a weapon, rifles, and light machine guns to protect their own Hamlet from VidCon.
The philosophy was that if there was local folks protecting themselves, that it would deny the VidCon from the right.
